data.body: WIP

data.title: Saving branch as scenes loses the connected signals
data.body:
Windows 7: Godot 2.1 alpha (current)

When exporting a scene that has been imported, signals that have been set up are not saved.

Steps:
Import roomCard.scn
Make the children editable, and uninstanced.
Add a signal (I chose the mouse exit signal) to Click.
Export the scene.
Import the scene again: the signal is now gone.

Can't provide a totally minimal project, but I can provide an instance of it happening in one of my current projects. Here's a link:
https://bitbucket.org/nosrick/monquest

data.title: Huge performance or scene start-up hit when using `self.` in nested for loops
data.body:
Ubuntu 16.04 - Godot vs. 2.0.3.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using `self.` in nested for loops it decreases performance dramatically (on the order of x100 to x1000 or so - time of execution). You'll notice that with `self.`, the time to execute the scene dramatically increases. It might not even be performance issue but just some bug related to the nested for loops because it takes a while to initialize and start the scene, not really to execute the script now that I think about it.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Make for loops (maybe only for nested for loops?!) and access a variable with `self.`.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I've uploaded a project file demonstrating the issue with comment in `map.gd` script where it makes the difference.
[godot_debug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/332930/godot_debug.zip)

It's a pity cause I really like using `self.` because it's more explicit and I'm an adept of the philosophy of code readability (over conciseness). Hope this is particular only to these for loops...

data.title: Script on an instanced node doesn't get saved.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10. Compile the latest source from GitHub.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After instancing a scene that has a script attached to its root node, editing that script doesn't get saved.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a scene, Scene A, put a script on its root node.
2. Create another scene, Scene B, instance Scene A in it. 
3. In Scene B, edit the script on the instanced Scene A.
4. Save.
5. Restart Godot.
6. Open Scene A and check the script attached to its root node. The changes didn't get saved.

ps: **the said script is never saved to a separate file.**

data.title: Ctrl + A while editing a script wants to add a node too.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Pro. Compile latest source from GitHub repo.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When editing a script on a node, Ctrl + A doesn't just select all, it brings up the add node dialog box too.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Put a script on a node in a scene. 
2. Edit the script.
3. While editing, press Ctrl + A.

data.title: More consistent look for CheckButton
data.body:
The current CheckButton doesn't look bad, but it uses red when it is switched off and that's inconsistent with other (blue) GUI elements as well as other programs, which show check buttons as filled when switched on.

For that reason, I suggest the (default) CheckButton is changed to this:

![Alternative color](https://i.imgur.com/gZnE1VU.png)

data.title: Changes X11 res_name to "Godot_Engine"
data.body:
Add additional/alternative WM_CLASS; only affects the game window, avoids redundancy and allows finer control in WMs (fixes #5265)

I release this code under the same terms as specified in Godot's LICENSE.md file (MIT license).

data.title: The mouse mode stays the same when an issue happens
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 15.10, Godot 2.0.2

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I wrote a little code to capture the mouse like this "Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED)"
the problem is when I add a new feature i get issues in the code just like every other human and when issues happen the editor pops up which is the problem, the mouse is still captured i can't type anything and can't use the editor's shortcuts to stop debugging or even close the window with "Alt+F4" the Ubuntu shortcut

**My Wish**
Add some feature that returns the mouse mode to un-captured, or saves the system's state before debugging the game and redo it when there are issues because the only solution that I can do is RESTART the computer which is why my development is SLOW

data.title: fails to compile with android_arch=x86
data.body:
Windows 10, latest head

Can compile fine with just "scons platform=android"  but with "scons platform=android android_arch=x86" it fails and gives the very well known (not very specific) error:

scons: **\* [platform\android\os_android.os] The system cannot find the file specified

Wanted to try and use x86 emulator on desktop, I suppose that can't be done right now.

data.title: Fix Android sensors polling rate on resume
Rust as a scripting language
data.body:
I saw that there's a ticket open for C# (_gag_), and wanted to know if there was any interest in utilizing Rust as a scripting language?

I know Mozilla just gave the Godot Engine team money for a WebGL2 port, and given that they're already updating their render engine to use Rust, perhaps we should get on the same bandwagon?

I saw that the "newcomer" argument was also made in the C#-related thread. Since Rust is a more modern language that embraces multiple programming paradigms, wouldn't this be more accommodating to adopt?

data.title: Change comment color in GDScript editor for additional readability
data.body:
The current comment color has poor contrast, and as a result isn't very readable (or pretty, IMHO).

Of course, everybody is going to have their own preferences here, but I think something like this is already more readable:

![Tango dark](https://pawelbx.github.io/emacs-theme-gallery/screenshots/dark/tango-dark/el.png)

In Godot's case, this color is too similar to the color for keywords, but something like this:

![Badger](https://pawelbx.github.io/emacs-theme-gallery/screenshots/dark/badger/el.png)

or a light shade of grey like this:

![Bubbleberry](https://pawelbx.github.io/emacs-theme-gallery/screenshots/dark/bubbleberry/el.png)

would also be more readable.

What do you think about it?

data.title: status != 0x8CD5 in RasterizerGLES2::canvas_light_shadow_buffer_create [Intel HD 3000, two monitors]
data.body:
OS: Windows 7 Home Premium 64 bits 
Godot Engine: v2.0.3 stable
Processor: Intel Core i5 2500k 
Graphics Card: Intel HD Graphics 3000
Driver date: 26/05/2015
Driver version: 9.17.10.4229

Issue description:
I tested some Godot examples and all was working fine. I connected my other old display device - an AOC 19" max res: 1680x1050.  After I'm using two display devices the error happened.
I was following the learning step-by-step tutorial and I was in the section 1.4.3 Scripting a scene.
Then I created this script as the instructions:

```
extends Panel

func _on_button_pressed():
    get_node("Label").set_text("HELLO!")

func _ready():
    get_node("Button").connect("pressed", self, "_on_button_pressed")
```

The script works but I get the following error:

```
Type: Error
Description:
Time: 0:00:01:0087
C Error: Condition ' status != 0x8CD5 ' is true. returned: RID()
C Source: drivers\gles2\rasterizer_gles2.cpp:8804
C Function: RasterizerGLES2::canvas_light_shadow_buffer_create
```

And in debugger output:

```
**Debugger Process Started**
Remote Debugger: Connection failed with status: 2", retrying in 1 sec.
EXEC PATHP??: C:\PortableApps\Godot_v2.0.3_stable_win64.exe
EXEC PATHP??: C:\PortableApps\Godot_v2.0.3_stable_win64.exe
EXEC PATHP??: C:\PortableApps\Godot_v2.0.3_stable_win64.exe
DETECTED MONITORS: 1
```

Will I have some problem with the error above or it's ok?

Sorry for my bad English.

![error1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20130832/16347201/ccc1278e-3a21-11e6-9451-1a6f2b454857.jpg)
![error2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20130832/16347200/ccc0f688-3a21-11e6-8008-8853ec761444.jpg)

data.title: Improve parallax mirroring algorithm
data.body:
Replaces the iterative approach currently used by the standard fmod() function.
Also fixes infinite looping that happens when the mirroring value is negative. *

*: Negative mirroring can make things look better in the editor when your 2D game scrolls "backwards". For instance, if your level scrolls from bottom to top and you have placed a parallax layer so its bottom edge matches the bottom edge of the initial viewport, by setting a negative Y mirroring, the mirror piece will be placed above, on level space instead of outside. Not very important and achievable perhaps by transforms but at least we get rid of the infinite loop in case someone tries.

data.title: Fix string array parameter check with jni
data.body:
I checked String array parameter type in java_glue.cpp/Java_org_godotengine_godot_GodotLib_method

```
print_line("rawString = "+String(rawString));  // it prints "rawString = [Ljava.lang.String;"
```

so I changed type name `"[java.lang.String"` to `"[Ljava.lang.String;"` in `get_jni_type` and `get_jni_sig`.
And now it works String array parameter well.

It parses java `String[]` to `[Ljava.lang.Object;` before.

data.title: Fix autosave when run on remote device
Scene/Filesystem panel resizes on switch
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Issue started at an unknown point in previous commits (after Node panel was introduced) and persists in current (9e0b605) master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When putting the Scene and Filesystem panels to share space, switching to Filesystem resizes the panel layout for no clear reason, as seen in these screenshots. It doesn't matter if you manually enlarge the area vertically, Filesystem will always take space away from the bottom panels. (so greedy)
![ihbl1jq](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/16334261/208a4a52-3a00-11e6-8e2f-dfd70ff3523d.png) ![tkqodnn](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/16334264/2595ad8e-3a00-11e6-839b-06cfcffe299d.png)

This is a minimal thing, a papercut if you will, but there's no obvious reason for it to behave like this.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Put Scene and Filesystem panels in the same position, with other panel at the bottom, and switch between them.

data.title: Optimized one-way collision loops.
data.body: Moved constant expressions out of loops, and terminated said loops when a valid contact is found. Should speed up one-way collisions with large contact lists.

data.title: [ HTML5 Game ] - FPS on Exported Project Capped up to 60. Can't go more than 60
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

HTML5 Platform - Any OS? - Godot 2.1alpha 60fa2b9

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
- What happened? FPS capped up to 60. And can't go > 60.
- What was Expected? It should harness the max power of the device (PC in my case) that shown by more FPS since the project is a simple one.

**Steps to reproduce:**

1.) Open one of examples or demos that comes with Godot.
2.) Do some setting that deal with FPS things (use_vsync, target_fps, print_fps)
3.) Export the project to HTML5 Platform
4.) Play the project using Firefox (or other)
5.) Now, FPS capped to 60.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

Just use examples & demos that comes with Godot.

Fixes #5375

data.title: Emit a signal when VideoPlayer stops?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any OS - Godot 2.X

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I'm trying to get the best performance out of a scene of mine that plays a video and adds subtitles (thanks to a custom GDScript I wrote).  
The video is played via a VideoStreamTheora and handled by a VideoPlayer Node.

Now, my scene constantly checks if the video is still playing so that it can move on when it stops. I've been looking around in godot's code and I can't find out the source of the `is_playing()` since it points to a `playback->is_playing()` (I think it checks for a bool value?), but anyways, I believe a signal would lay off a little bit  if not more  stress out of CPU (on a side note, I see that Theora drops many frames).

So, I looked at the signals singleton but found out (remembered, actually) that "finished" is already a signal that exists for animation, so I'm not sure if the signal can conflict with the video if we were to point both towards it. If this is the case, it's best to make a signal entirely for streaming.  
If this is not feasible, what can be an alternative?
